name: 999 Call Simulator
description:
The 999 Call Simulator is a voice-interactive educational tool designed to bridge the gap between First Aid theory and real-world application. It simulates a high-pressure emergency call, forcing the user to verbally communicate with an AI operator. Unlike standard multiple-choice quizzes, this simulator requires the user to speak clearly, answer specific triage questions, and react to changing medical situations in real-time. It is designed to practice the Primary Survey (DR ABC), Secondary Survey (S.A.M.P.L.E / AVPU), and specific Outdoor First Aid protocols.

Feature Summary

Core Interaction
Universal Emergency dialing: The simulation begins with a realistic keypad that accepts major international emergency numbers (999, 112, 911, 000, etc.) to initiate the call.
Voice Recognition & Text-to-Speech: The app listens to the user's spoken answers and responds verbally using distinct voices for the "Switchboard Operator" and the "Ambulance/Police Dispatcher."
Fallback Text Input: Includes a manual text entry box for users in noisy environments or devices without microphone support.

Advanced Triage Logic (The Script)
Primary Survey Enforcement: Prioritizes critical checks immediately: Breathing, Consciousness, Location.
AVPU Responsiveness Scale: If the casualty is awake, the operator drills down to check if they are Alert or responding to Voice. If they fail these checks, they are marked "Unresponsive."
Smart S.A.M.P.L.E. History: Conducts a secondary survey (Signs, Allergies, Medications, Past History, Last Oral Intake, Events).
Smart Logic: If the patient is marked "Unresponsive," the simulator intelligently skips questions the patient cannot answer (e.g., "What did you last eat?").
Associative Keyword Recognition: The AI links context clues to medical issues (e.g., "Tree/Ladder" triggers Spinal protocol; "River/Snow" triggers Hypothermia protocol; "Peanuts/Sting" triggers Anaphylaxis protocol).

Medical Protocols
Cardiac Arrest (CPR Mode): Recognizes "not breathing" or "agonal gasps." Activates a 120 BPM Audio Metronome to pace chest compressions. Provides an Encouragement Loop every 60 seconds (e.g., "You are keeping them alive, don't stop").
Diabetes: Detects keywords like "insulin" or "sugar," checks for confusion/hypoglycemia, and advises on glucose administration only if the patient is alert.
Anaphylaxis: Differentiates between mild reactions and severe breathing difficulties; advises on Adrenaline Auto-Injectors (EpiPen).
Trauma & Bleeding: Distinguishes between catastrophic (spurting) bleeding and standard wounds, advising on direct pressure, elevation, or tourniquets.
Environmental (Outdoor First Aid): Hypothermia: Advises on shelter, insulation from the ground, and warm drinks. Hyperthermia: Advises on shade, cooling, and hydration.

Dynamic "Real-World" Elements
Dynamic ETA Generation: Calculates arrival time based on Location (Urban vs. Remote/Hills) and Severity. Example: A cardiac arrest in a city might get an 8-minute ETA, while a broken ankle on a mountain gets 120+ minutes.
Priority Upgrading: If the patientâ€™s condition deteriorates (e.g., they stop breathing during the call), the operator "upgrades" the call to Category 1 and provides a new, faster ETA.
Auto-Announcements: Seamlessly weaves reassurance ("Help has been arranged...") into the conversation between questions.

"Monitor Mode" (Post-Call Support)
The simulator does not end after the questions are answered. It enters a "Monitor Loop" where the operator stays on the line. Reacts to Changes: The user can say "They are going to be sick" (triggers Airway advice) or "They stopped breathing" (triggers CPR protocol). Time Checks: The user can ask "How much longer?" anytime to hear the remaining ETA.
